arm_group.description: Participants will attend a group behavioral treatment class and follow-up visits.
Subjects will not attend group behavioral treatment class.

brief_summary.textblock:
This three-site randomized controlled trial compares the effectiveness and
      cost-effectiveness of a group-administered behavioral treatment program to no treatment.
      Women with stress, urgency, or mixed urinary incontinence will be recruited and screened
      centrally, evaluated clinically at each of three study sites, and random assigned to one of
      two treatment arms:  1. Group behavioral treatment or 2. No treatment.  Group treatment
      modalities have the potential to reach a larger population of older women with urinary
      incontinence, not only in the traditional medical settings, but also in community settings.
      The investigators hypothesize that group behavioral treatment will be more effective than no
      treatment.  The investigators hypothesize that the group treatment will be cost-effective
      compared to no treatment.

clinical_study.brief_title: Group Learning Achieves Decreased Incidents of Lower Urinary Symptoms

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          1. Female

          2. Aged 55 years or older

          3. Ability to understand and read English

          4. Stress, urgency, or mixed urgency and stress UI (by self report)

          5. On the ICIQ-UI SF, frequency of leakage at least a 1 ("about once a week or less
             often") on item #1 and volume of urine loss at least a 2 ("a small amount") on item
             #2.

          6. Symptoms of three months duration or longer (on history)

          7. Passing score (i.e., categorized as "probably not demented") on the MiniCog Test

          8. Timed "Up and Go" Test (TUG) score of < 20 seconds

          9. Willing to undergo vaginal/pelvic examination

         10. Signed informed consent form

        Exclusion Criteria:

          1. History of bladder cancer

          2. Non-ambulatory (participant confined to bed or wheelchair)

          3. Persistent pelvic pain (defined as daily pelvic pain > 3 months)

          4. History of neurologic diseases (e.g. CVA, Parkinson's disease, multiple sclerosis,
             epilepsy, spinal cord tumor or trauma, spina bifida, symptomatic herniated disc)

          5. Previous treatment for UI, including surgery or formal behavioral treatment (pelvic
             floor muscle training, biofeedback, pelvic floor electrical stimulation, percutaneous
             tibial nerve stimulation, sacral neuromodulation, botox or other periurethral
             injection)

          6. Actively taking UI medications (participant currently on pharmacologic therapy for
             incontinence and/or OAB (may have a 2-week washout prior to randomization)

          7. Other urinary conditions or procedures that may affect continence status (e.g.
             urethral diverticula, previous augmentation cystoplasty or artificial urinary
             sphincter; implanted nerve stimulators for urinary symptoms)

          8. Participation in another research study that may influence the results of this trial

          9. Pregnancy or intention to be pregnant in the next 6 months

         10. Pelvic organ prolapse protruding past the introitus (at rest or persisting after
             strain)

         11. Absolute absence of pelvic floor muscle strength manifested by zero on Brink test

         12. Evidence of UTI by urine dipstick (leukocytes > +1), presence of hematuria (> +1), or
             proteinuria (> +2).  Participants may be re-screened after treatment with antibiotics
             or if hematuria work-up is negative.

         13. History of > 2 recurrent UTI's within the past year; more than one UTI within past 6
             months

         14. Post void residual urine volume > 150 cc

             -

intervention.description: Group Behavioral Treatment class is a two hour class taught by certified interventionist covering urinary system anatomy, bladder health and self management strategies, pelvic floor training, pelvic floor muscle contracting techniques, and bladder training.  Slides and handouts supplement the content of the class.

facility.name: University of Pennsylvania Health System, Urology

clinical_study.official_title: Group Learning Achieves Decreased Incidents of Lower Urinary Symptoms

primary_outcome.description: The primary outcome will be self-reported urinary incontinence severity as measured by the International Consultation on Incontinence questionnaire-short form (ICI-Q).  Baseline data will be compared to the 3,6, 9 and 12 month data.
primary_outcome.measure: Group Behavioral Treatment Effectiveness as shown by changes in urinary incontinence severity.

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

secondary_outcome.description: Measure resource use and utilitities and compare the difference in incontinence management costs and utilities between treatment and control group.

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Endpoint Classification: Efficacy Study, Intervention Model: Parallel Assignment, Masking: Open Label, Primary Purpose: Treatment
